channel.title: Stories from wired.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best wired.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: To Run My Best Marathon At Age 44, I Had To Outrun My Past
item.description: After 20 years of long-distance competition, I ran my fastest. All it took was tech, training and a new understanding of my life.

item.title: 25 Years After Oklahoma City, Domestic Terrorism Is On The Rise
item.description: In an exclusive interview with WIRED, FBI director Christopher Wray discusses a scourge that "moves at the speed of social media."

item.title: A Vital Hack Could Turn Medical Devices Into Ventilators
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of lower-grade breathing devices are going unused because manufacturers say they can't perform life-saving functions. But a new patch might change that.
item.kicker: HACK THE PLANET, SAVE THE WORLD

item.title: Everyone Is Trying To Sell Medical Equipment — Even On LinkedIn
item.description: With face masks and other protective gear in short supply, speculators and pop-up brokers are finding customers on an unlikely platform.

item.title: AI Uncovers A Potential Treatment For COVID-19 Patients
item.description: Software suggested an arthritis drug might quell an out-of-control immune response that damages the lungs. Now it's being tested in a clinical trial.

item.title: How A Rare Form Of Dementia 'Erased' The Mind Of A Star Programmer
item.description: Compared to Alzheimer's, stories about frontotemporal dementia is less well-known. This is the story of how this rare form of dementia changed the lives of Lee Holloway, a brilliant engineer and one of the co-founders of internet security company Cloudflare, and those around him forever.

item.title: How A Pudgy Porpoise May Save Other Animals From Extinction
item.description: The vaquita, an icon of the Gulf of California, is swiftly dying out. But its strange DNA could hold valuable lessons for other threatened species.

item.title: What Does COVID-19 Do To Your Brain?
item.description: Scientists are racing to figure out why some patients also develop neurological ailments like confusion, stroke, seizure, or loss of smell.

item.title: Uncovering Operation NEPTUN, The Cold War's Most Daring Disinformation Campaign
item.description: Rumored Nazi treasure, a dark Bohemian lake, an unsuspecting TV crew — and a brilliant spy to put it all together.

item.title: What If COVID-19 Returns Every Year, Like The Common Cold?
item.description: A new Harvard study models how long we'd have to keep social distancing if the virus turns out to be seasonal, like its coronavirus cousins. It could be years.

item.title: The Devastating Decline Of A Brilliant Young Coder
item.description: Lee Holloway programmed internet security firm Cloudflare into being. But then he became apathetic, distant, and unpredictable — for a long time, no one could make sense of it.

item.title: The Pandemic Could Be An Opportunity To Remake Cities
item.description: Cities from Bogota to Oakland are closing streets to make room for pedestrians and bikers. Urbanists think we'd be healthier if such changes were permanent.

item.title: Nine Amazon Workers Describe The Daily Risks They Face In The Pandemic
item.description: "This job is essential because people need deliveries, but it's also essential for me because I need the money to feed my family."
item.kicker: WORKING TOO HARD FOR THE MONEY

item.title: The FDA Asks Companies To Stop Selling Ranitidine
item.description: The federal agency cites concerns that the widely-used antacid may contain a possibly cancer-causing contaminant called NDMA.
item.kicker: THEY HAVE MADE A HUGE MISTAKE

item.title: Netflix's 'Space Force' Looks Like A TV Lover's Dream
item.description: Also, Lisa Kudrow is now part of the cast, so that's cool.

item.title: I Am Not At All Relaxed By Animal Crossing
item.description: Millions of people have found comfort in the Switch smash hit. I, however, have found myself trapped in a endless cycle of kawaii capitalism.

item.title: How To Escape From A Sunken Submarine
item.description: First of all, you can't just open the hatch when you're trapped at the bottom of the ocean. But there is a way out — it requires physics and some audacity.

item.title: In Italy, The TV Show 'Big Brother' Is Now Everyone's Reality
item.description: Contestants on Italy's version of "Big Brother" had a jump-start on life under quarantine. Now they return to a world both familiar and alien.

item.title: The Unbearable Lightness Of 'Animal Crossing'
item.description: "Animal Crossing" has recently gone what, in a less awful time, we might have called viral.

item.title: Turns Out, Traffic Spreads Like The Coronavirus
item.description: Researchers use models meant for infectious diseases to show how congestion proliferates. That may mean a vaccine for traffic jams is on the horizon.
item.kicker: WE'RE GONNA HAVE CAR QUARANTINE NEXT

item.title: The Power Plant Of The Future Is Right In Your Home
item.description: If we want more renewable energy, our grids will have to manage themselves. A small experiment in Colorado is lighting the way.

item.title: How Un-Miracle Drugs Could Help Tame The Pandemic
item.description: Scientists are scrambling to create Covid-19 antivirals. But what if medicines we already have are good enough to buy patients more time?

item.title: Japan Is Racing To Test Favipiravir, A Drug To Treat COVID-19
item.description: Based on a compound discovered in 1998, the antiviral Favipiravir is already being used in Japan and Turkey. Its maker? A subsidiary of Fujifilm.

item.title: The Asian Countries That Beat COVID-19 Have To Do It Again
item.description: "When it's near the peak, and you have to manage it, you start to do as much of the mitigation strategy as possible, so you flatten the curve. Then you try to wait and see where you are, and if you lift it too early, you get a resurgence."

item.title: How To Refuel A Nuclear Power Plant During A Pandemic
item.description: To swap out the spent uranium rods, hundreds of technicians from around the country must work in close quarters for weeks. That's a challenge during a quarantine.

item.title: The Coronavirus Lockdown Is A Threat For Many Animals, Not A Blessing
item.description: You may have seen recent videos of goats roaming an empty town. But for more vulnerable species, like rhinos, this shutdown poses a great danger.

item.title: Wyoming Confronts Its Wind-Powered Destiny
item.description: The Cowboy State should be a renewable energy juggernaut, but it's dominated by fossils fuels. Next step: Thinking of the future instead of digging up the past.

item.title: Has A One-Time Poultry Farmer Invented The Future Of Refrigeration?
item.description: Mechanical cooling revolutionized the global food supply — and accelerated global warming. Peter Dearman's liquid air engine could change all that.

item.title: A Creator Of The Ebola Vaccine Has Hope For Slowing COVID-19
item.description: Gary Kobinger says a vaccine targeting groups like the elderly could be ready in less than a year, and control measures are slowing the disease's spread.

item.title: It's Time To Face Facts, America: Masks Work
item.description: Official advice has been confusing, but the science isn't hard to grasp. Everyone should cover up.

item.title: What To Do If You (Or A Loved One) Might Have COVID-19
item.description: Here's our guide to what symptoms you should look out for, and how to respond if you've been exposed.

item.title: Why Life During A Pandemic Feels So Surreal
item.description: The study of the surreal has mostly concerned Dali's paintings and Kafka's writings. But there are psychological reasons why every day seems so otherworldly.

item.title: This Is Not The Apocalypse You Were Looking For
item.description: Pop culture has been inundated with catastrophe porn for decades. None of it has prepared us for our new reality.

item.title: The Mathematics Of Predicting The Course Of The Coronavirus
item.description: Epidemiologists are using complex models to help policymakers get ahead of the COVID-19 pandemic. But the leap from equations to decisions is a long one.

item.title: Charge A Car Battery In 5 Minutes? That's The Plan
item.description: Several companies have built lithium-ion batteries that can fully charge in a matter of minutes. Their next goal: getting these into electric vehicles.

item.title: 14 Apps and Tools to Stave Off Cabin Fever
item.description: Millions of people are staying inside for the indefinite future. Here are a few apps to help you socialize, exercise and meditate from your own home.

item.title: You Can See The Coronavirus From Space
item.description: Satellite images show empty cities, popup mega-hospitals and other signs of the pandemic's spread.

item.title: The Ibuprofen Debate Reveals The Danger Of COVID-19 Rumors
item.description: An online furor over whether it's safe to use the fever reducer reveals how people are sharing incomplete — and sometimes bad — information.

item.title: Engineers Made A DIY Face Shield. Now, It's Helping Doctors
item.description: After a hospital put out a call for protective gear, three friends developed a product in a few days. Their design is now being manufactured by Ford.

item.title: America's Electricity Is Safe From The Coronavirus — For Now
item.description: Utilities and grid operators are well-prepared to handle the pandemic, but a second wave of the virus later this year could be disastrous.

item.title: The Promising Math Behind 'Flattening The Curve'
item.description: Infectious diseases spread exponentially, yes, but only in the beginning. Thank God.

item.title: Jewelry. Candles. Hand Sanitizer. Welcome To Coronavirus Etsy
item.description: On the online marketplace more often associated with handmade and vintage goods, sellers are pivoting to meet pandemic-related demands.

item.title: An Old Source For Potential New COVID-19 Drugs: Blood Serum
item.description: A 100-year-old way to beat disease could help researchers figure out how to harness the antibodies from earlier patients to help the newly infected.

item.title: Most Kids Only Get Mildly Sick From COVID-19 — But Not All
item.description: New studies suggest that while children still fare better than adults, babies, toddlers and kids with other conditions remain at risk.

item.title: If Robots Steal So Many Jobs, Why Aren't They Saving Us Now?
item.description: We've been led to believe that robots and AI are replacing humans en masse. But this economic catastrophe is blowing up that myth.

item.title: Why Don't We Just Ban Targeted Advertising?
item.description: From protecting privacy to saving the free press, it may be the single best way to fix the internet.

item.title: The Mom Who Took On Purdue Pharma For Its OxyContin Marketing
item.description: After her daughter died of an overdose, Marianne Skolek Perez became an advocate on behalf of OxyContin victims, delving into how the drug was being sold.
item.kicker: 'DID YOU GET THE BAD GUYS YET?'

item.title: How To Disinfect Everything: Coronavirus Home Cleaning Tips
item.description: These are our in-depth best practices for keeping yourself (and just about everything else) clean and virus-free.
item.kicker: WE WASH OUR HANDS OF THIS

item.title: Go Ahead, Stream All You Want. The Internet Is Fine — For Now
item.description: Netflix is slowing streams in Europe in an effort to preserve bandwidth amid the pandemic. But US providers seem to be holding up to the surge in usage.
item.kicker: PROTECT THE NET AT ALL COSTS

item.title: The Doctor Who Helped Defeat Smallpox Explains What's Coming
item.description: Epidemiologist Larry Brilliant, who warned of pandemic in 2006, says we can beat the novel coronavirus — but first, we need lots more testing.
